title: 106_s2417
content: The Act titled "Water Pollution Program Enhancements Act of 2000" defines key terms like Administrator, NAPA Study, and NAS Study. It also addresses funding for water pollution control measures. The Water Pollution Program Enhancements Act of 2000 authorizes $250,000,000 annually for grants to States and interstate agencies for pollution prevention and enforcement activities. $50,000,000 of the funding is designated for State activities. The Water Pollution Program Enhancements Act of 2000 authorizes $500,000,000 annually for States for monitoring data collection, list improvement, total maximum daily load allocations, and watershed management strategies under section 319 of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act. The Water Pollution Program Enhancements Act of 2000 authorizes $500,000,000 annually for States for monitoring data collection, list improvement, total maximum daily load allocations, and watershed management strategies under section 319 of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act. Of this amount, $7,500,000 may be used for groundwater quality projects, and $200,000,000 is allocated for States to provide grants for nonpoint source pollution control projects to improve impaired water quality. Grants under this paragraph shall not exceed 90 percent. The recipient may use funds from other Federal programs and eligible contributions to satisfy the non-Federal share. Grants are not available for projects required by law. SEC. 4. REPORTS TO CONGRESS. The Administrator will contract with the National Academy of Sciences to conduct a study on the scientific basis of total maximum daily loads under the Federal Water Pollution Control Act and the effectiveness of alternative programs in reducing pollution. The study must be submitted to the Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure of the House of Representatives within 18 months of the enactment of this Act. The Administrator will contract with the National Academy of Public Administrators to conduct a study on the effectiveness of existing pollution reduction programs. $2,000,000 is authorized for the study. The Administrator will contract with the National Academy of Public Administrators to conduct a study on pollution reduction programs. $3,000,000 is authorized for the study, with a report due to Congress within 18 months of enactment. Passed the Senate on October 10, 2000.
